title: Mastering Headshot Direction: The 'Write It Down' Technique
summary: Headshot photographer Peter Hurley shares his strategy for maintaining consistent and effective direction during photoshoots. He advises photographers to record every phrase or word that successfully elicits a reaction and keep these notes visible during sessions—either taped to equipment or on a digital screen—to ensure they never run out of ideas when uninspired or tired.

steps.action: Write down every phrase, word, or scenario that successfully gets a reaction from a client immediately after it works.
Tape the written lists of directions to the back of your studio lights or stands so they are always in your line of sight while shooting.
For modern workflows, keep a Google Doc or digital note open on your tethered computer screen for quick reference.
Use visual aids, such as a chart of facial expressions corresponding to names or emotions, to help direct subjects.
Review and curate your list of directions regularly, organizing them into a master document to keep your 'shtick' fresh.

key_takeaways: Don't rely solely on memory or inspiration; fatigue can make you forget your best directions.
Create a repository of 'go-to' phrases (Hurleyisms) that reliably provoke expressions.
Keep your cheat sheet visible during the shoot to maintain flow when you get stuck.
Even nonsensical or funny phrases can work if delivered with conviction to get a reaction.
Continuously update your list with new ideas to prevent your direction from becoming stale.
